questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents with sudden onset right hemiplegia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Intraventricular hemorrhage

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The CT image shows hyperdense blood localized within the ventricular system, particularly in the lateral and third ventricles, consistent with intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH).
  • • Key points:
  • • 1. CT Findings:
  • • The white hyperdense areas represent acute hemorrhage within the ventricles. There is no obvious parenchymal source of hemorrhage visible in this section, suggesting isolated IVH.
  • • The white hyperdense areas represent acute hemorrhage within the ventricles.
  • • There is no obvious parenchymal source of hemorrhage visible in this section, suggesting isolated IVH.
  • • 2. Possible Causes:
  • • IVH can occur as a primary event or as an extension of hypertensive hemorrhage (common in the basal ganglia) or a brainstem bleed. While the source is not directly visible on this section, the intraventricular blood is clear.
  • • IVH can occur as a primary event or as an extension of hypertensive hemorrhage (common in the basal ganglia) or a brainstem bleed. While the source is not directly visible on this section, the intraventricular blood is clear.
  • • 3. Clinical Presentation:
  • • The patient presents with sudden onset right hemiplegia, which can occur due to secondary effects of IVH, such as pressure on adjacent structures or involvement of motor pathways.
  • • The patient presents with sudden onset right hemiplegia, which can occur due to secondary effects of IVH, such as pressure on adjacent structures or involvement of motor pathways.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hypertensive hemorrhage: Hypertensive hemorrhage often involves the basal ganglia or thalamus and may extend into the ventricles. However, this image does not show a parenchymal bleed, making isolated IVH the correct answer.
  • • Option A. Hypertensive hemorrhage:
  • • Option B. Berry aneurysm rupture: Berry aneurysm rupture typically causes subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), with blood in the basal cisterns or subarachnoid spaces. The characteristic "star of death" appearance is not present here.
  • • Option B. Berry aneurysm rupture:
  • • Option C. Pontine hemorrhage: Pontine hemorrhage would appear as hyperdensity in the brainstem and is associated with coma, quadriplegia, and pinpoint pupils. These findings are absent in this case.
  • • Option C. Pontine hemorrhage:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) is identified by blood localized in the ventricular system on CT. It may occur independently or as an extension of other intracranial hemorrhages.
  • ➤ Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) is identified by blood localized in the ventricular system on CT. It may occur independently or as an extension of other intracranial hemorrhages.

questions.text: What is the most useful investigation to confirm the diagnosis of the patient with following condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Manometry

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image provided shows the characteristic "bird-beak" sign, which is indicative of achalasia cardia . Achalasia is a condition caused by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to relax, leading to obstruction and dilation of the proximal esophagus. The smooth tapering seen in the image supports this diagnosis.
  • • achalasia cardia
  • • Manometry is the investigation of choice for confirming achalasia cardia. It measures esophageal motility and the pressure at the LES. In achalasia, manometry findings include:
  • • Manometry
  • • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body. Increased LES pressure or incomplete relaxation of the LES.
  • • Absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body.
  • • Increased LES pressure or incomplete relaxation of the LES.
  • • While other tests can support the diagnosis, manometry provides definitive confirmation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Timed barium swallow: This test can show delayed emptying of barium and the height of the barium column at timed intervals (e.g., 1, 5, and 10 minutes). It is useful for assessing the severity of achalasia and for follow-up after treatment but is not the gold standard for diagnosis.
  • • Option A. Timed barium swallow:
  • • Option B. UGIE (Upper Gastrointestinal Endoscopy): Endoscopy is used to rule out secondary causes of achalasia, such as esophageal carcinoma or peptic strictures. It is not the most useful test for confirming the diagnosis of achalasia cardia.
  • • Option B. UGIE (Upper Gastrointestinal Endoscopy):
  • • Option D. 24-hr pH monitoring: This test is specific for diagnosing gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and is the least useful option for confirming achalasia cardia. It does not provide information about esophageal motility or LES relaxation.
  • • Option D. 24-hr pH monitoring:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Achalasia cardia is confirmed by manometry, which shows absent peristalsis and incomplete relaxation of the LES. The "bird-beak" sign on a barium swallow study is a hallmark radiological finding in achalasia.
  • ➤ Achalasia cardia is confirmed by manometry, which shows absent peristalsis and incomplete relaxation of the LES.
  • ➤ The "bird-beak" sign on a barium swallow study is a hallmark radiological finding in achalasia.

questions.text: A newborn baby in the nursery has bilious emesis. The patient has voided once but has not yet passed meconium. Physical examination shows a hypotonic neonate with a flat face, prominent tongue, low-set ears, and slanted palpebral fissures. A nasogastric tube is placed, and abdominal x-ray is shown below. In addition to echocardiogram, which of the following is the best next step in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Surgical repair

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The newborn presents with features of Down syndrome (flat face, prominent tongue, low-set ears, and slanted palpebral fissures) and bilious emesis , which is an indication of intestinal obstruction. The abdominal X-ray shows the double bubble sign , a hallmark of duodenal atresia . Duodenal atresia occurs when the duodenum fails to recanalize during development, leading to complete obstruction.
  • • Down syndrome
  • • bilious emesis
  • • double bubble sign
  • • duodenal atresia
  • • The next step in management is surgical repair to correct the obstruction and allow normal passage of food. Delay in intervention may result in severe complications such as perforation or sepsis.
  • • surgical repair
  • • An echocardiogram is also important in patients with Down syndrome, as congenital heart defects are common in this population and must be addressed before anesthesia and surgery.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Barium meal: A barium meal is contraindicated in cases of obstruction, as it can worsen symptoms and does not add diagnostic value in confirmed cases of duodenal atresia.
  • • Option A. Barium meal:
  • • Option B. CECT abdomen: While a contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) might be useful in diagnosing complex causes of obstruction in some cases, it is unnecessary in this scenario. The diagnosis of duodenal atresia has already been established based on clinical presentation and the double bubble sign on X-ray. CECT would not alter management in this emergency situation.
  • • Option B. CECT abdomen:
  • • Option C. Rectal biopsy: Rectal biopsy is used to diagnose Hirschsprung disease , which may coexist with Down syndrome. However, in an acute setting where duodenal obstruction is the immediate concern, addressing Hirschsprung disease is not a priority. The biopsy can be considered later if indicated.
  • • Option C. Rectal biopsy:
  • • Hirschsprung disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "double bubble sign" on abdominal X-ray is a hallmark of duodenal atresia. Duodenal atresia is commonly associated with Down syndrome. The management of duodenal atresia is surgical repair to relieve the obstruction.
  • ➤ The "double bubble sign" on abdominal X-ray is a hallmark of duodenal atresia.
  • ➤ Duodenal atresia is commonly associated with Down syndrome.
  • ➤ The management of duodenal atresia is surgical repair to relieve the obstruction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to AIIMS OPD with complaints of amenorrhea for the past six months. She has a history of two previous pregnancies, both of which resulted in miscarriages followed by dilation and curettage procedure after her last miscarriage. Physical examination reveals a normal BMI. She has a past history of pulmonary TB for which she completed ATT. She underwent a HSG which is shown here. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Asherman Syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The HSG (hysterosalpingography) image shows intrauterine filling defects , which are characteristic of intrauterine adhesions or synechiae , consistent with Asherman Syndrome . The clinical history of dilation and curettage (D&C) after miscarriages is a significant risk factor for Asherman Syndrome, as D&C can cause trauma to the uterine lining, leading to adhesions.
  • • intrauterine filling defects
  • • intrauterine adhesions or synechiae
  • • Asherman Syndrome
  • • Key findings in this case:
  • • Key findings in this case:
  • • Amenorrhea following D&C. HSG showing intrauterine filling defects (areas that do not fill with contrast). History of recurrent pregnancy loss and uterine procedures.
  • • Amenorrhea following D&C.
  • • HSG showing intrauterine filling defects (areas that do not fill with contrast).
  • • History of recurrent pregnancy loss and uterine procedures.
  • • Although the patient has a history of pulmonary TB, the fallopian tubes appear normal in this HSG image, with no evidence of tubal blockage or hydrosalpinx, ruling out GU TB in this case.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS): PCOS is characterized by anovulation, hyperandrogenism, and polycystic ovaries seen on ultrasound. HSG findings are typically normal in PCOS, and it does not present with intrauterine filling defects.
  • • Option A. Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS):
  • • Option B. GU TB: Genitourinary tuberculosis (GU TB) can cause tubal blockages, hydrosalpinx, or adhesions. However, this HSG image shows normal tubal patency with normal peritoneal spill, making GU TB less likely.
  • • Option B. GU TB:
  • • normal tubal patency
  • • Option D. Endometriosis: Endometriosis does not cause intrauterine filling defects and is typically diagnosed via laparoscopy or the presence of chocolate cysts on ultrasound. HSG findings in endometriosis are often normal.
  • • Option D. Endometriosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asherman Syndrome is characterized by intrauterine adhesions that result in filling defects on HSG. It commonly occurs after uterine trauma, such as dilation and curettage (D&C). Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a key diagnostic tool for identifying intrauterine adhesions.
  • ➤ Asherman Syndrome is characterized by intrauterine adhesions that result in filling defects on HSG.
  • ➤ It commonly occurs after uterine trauma, such as dilation and curettage (D&C).
  • ➤ Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a key diagnostic tool for identifying intrauterine adhesions.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with prolonged cough for 7 months, streaky hemoptysis for 1 month and fever for 4 days. Chest X-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Round pneumonia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The chest X-ray shows a well-defined, rounded opacity on the right side, which is characteristic of round pneumonia . In children, pneumonia can appear as a rounded consolidation due to the underdeveloped collateral ventilation pathways, such as pores of Kohn and canals of Lambert , which allow the infection to spread diffusely in adults but not in children. As a result, the infection becomes localized and assumes a rounded morphology.
  • • well-defined, rounded opacity
  • • round pneumonia
  • • pores of Kohn
  • • canals of Lambert
  • • Key clinical features in this case:
  • • Key clinical features in this case:
  • • Prolonged cough, fever, and streaky hemoptysis: These symptoms are consistent with an infective etiology. Well-defined opacity on X-ray: Suggestive of a localized consolidation. Pediatric age group: Round pneumonia is seen more commonly in children because of the anatomical differences in their lungs.
  • • Prolonged cough, fever, and streaky hemoptysis: These symptoms are consistent with an infective etiology.
  • • Prolonged cough, fever, and streaky hemoptysis:
  • • Well-defined opacity on X-ray: Suggestive of a localized consolidation.
  • • Well-defined opacity on X-ray:
  • • Pediatric age group: Round pneumonia is seen more commonly in children because of the anatomical differences in their lungs.
  • • Pediatric age group:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Congenital lobar hyperinflation: This is a congenital anomaly characterized by overexpansion of a lung lobe, typically presenting with respiratory distress in neonates or infants. On imaging, it would appear as a hyperlucent (black) area due to excess air, not as a white opacity.
  • • Option A. Congenital lobar hyperinflation:
  • • Option B. Lung abscess: Lung abscesses are characterized by a round opacity with an air-fluid level on imaging. This is absent in the given X-ray. Abscesses are also commonly associated with anaerobic polymicrobial infections and typically present with systemic symptoms such as chills and severe sepsis.
  • • Option B. Lung abscess:
  • • round opacity with an air-fluid level
  • • Option D. Congenital thoracic malformation: This is a very nonspecific term encompassing a variety of developmental abnormalities of the lungs and thoracic cavity. These are usually identified incidentally or present with respiratory symptoms in neonates or young children. The imaging findings do not support this diagnosis.
  • • Option D. Congenital thoracic malformation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Round pneumonia is a pediatric condition caused by localized consolidation due to underdeveloped collateral ventilation pathways. On X-ray, round pneumonia presents as a well-defined rounded opacity, often misinterpreted as a mass or abscess.
  • ➤ Round pneumonia is a pediatric condition caused by localized consolidation due to underdeveloped collateral ventilation pathways.
  • ➤ On X-ray, round pneumonia presents as a well-defined rounded opacity, often misinterpreted as a mass or abscess.

questions.text: A 8 month old child after vaccination presents to the emergency with incessant crying and legs drawn up. X-ray abdomen showed signs of free air. USG is done next which shows the following. What will you do next?
questions.correct_answer: A. Plan for urgent surgical exploration
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Plan for urgent surgical exploration

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The ultrasound image shows the characteristic target sign (or donut sign) , which is diagnostic of intussusception . Intussusception is a condition in which part of the intestine telescopes into itself, causing obstruction. In most cases of uncomplicated intussusception, an air or contrast enema can be both diagnostic and therapeutic.
  • • target sign (or donut sign)
  • • intussusception
  • • air or contrast enema
  • • However, in this case, the presence of free air on X-ray indicates perforation , which is a complication of intussusception. Once perforation is detected, non-surgical interventions such as an enema are contraindicated because they can exacerbate the situation by causing leakage of bowel contents into the peritoneal cavity, leading to peritonitis.
  • • free air on X-ray
  • • perforation
  • • non-surgical interventions such as an enema are contraindicated
  • • The only appropriate next step in this case is urgent surgical exploration to address the perforation and manage the intussusception. This is a surgical emergency.
  • • urgent surgical exploration
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Air enema: While air enema is the first-line treatment for intussusception in most cases, it is contraindicated when perforation is present due to the risk of worsening contamination and peritonitis.
  • • Option B. Air enema:
  • • Option C. CT scan: A CT scan is unnecessary in this emergency scenario, as the diagnosis of intussusception is already confirmed via ultrasound, and the X-ray has shown free air indicating perforation. Delaying surgical intervention to perform a CT scan could worsen the patient’s condition.
  • • Option C. CT scan:
  • • Option D. MRI: MRI is not indicated in this scenario. It is time-consuming, expensive, and adds no additional value to the diagnosis of intussusception or the detection of perforation.
  • • Option D. MRI:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intussusception can present with characteristic signs such as the target or donut sign on ultrasound. Free air on an X-ray indicates perforation and requires urgent surgical exploration. Non-surgical interventions such as enemas are contraindicated when perforation is suspected or confirmed.
  • ➤ Intussusception can present with characteristic signs such as the target or donut sign on ultrasound.
  • ➤ Free air on an X-ray indicates perforation and requires urgent surgical exploration.
  • ➤ Non-surgical interventions such as enemas are contraindicated when perforation is suspected or confirmed.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the images shown?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mafucci disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The images show:
  • • Multiple enchondromas (benign cartilaginous tumors seen in the bones). Soft tissue hemangiomas , visible as bluish nodular lesions.
  • • Multiple enchondromas (benign cartilaginous tumors seen in the bones).
  • • Multiple enchondromas
  • • Soft tissue hemangiomas , visible as bluish nodular lesions.
  • • Soft tissue hemangiomas
  • • Maffucci disease is characterized by the combination of enchondromas and soft tissue hemangiomas . The presence of phleboliths (calcified foci in hemangiomas) on the X-ray supports the diagnosis, as these are characteristic of hemangiomas.
  • • enchondromas
  • • soft tissue hemangiomas
  • • phleboliths
  • • Key diagnostic features in Maffucci disease:
  • • Key diagnostic features in Maffucci disease:
  • • Multiple enchondromas, most commonly in the hands and feet. Soft tissue hemangiomas, which may present as bluish lesions on clinical examination. Phleboliths seen on X-ray, representing calcifications within the hemangiomas.
  • • Multiple enchondromas, most commonly in the hands and feet.
  • • Soft tissue hemangiomas, which may present as bluish lesions on clinical examination.
  • • Phleboliths seen on X-ray, representing calcifications within the hemangiomas.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia: This condition involves replacement of normal bone with fibrous tissue, leading to deformities. It commonly affects long bones and craniofacial bones and does not present with soft tissue hemangiomas or phleboliths.
  • • Option A. Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia:
  • • Option B. Ollier disease: Ollier disease also involves multiple enchondromas but lacks the soft tissue hemangiomas seen in Maffucci disease.
  • • Option B. Ollier disease:
  • • Option D. Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome: This syndrome, also known as hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT), involves telangiectasias and arteriovenous malformations (AVMs). It typically presents with epistaxis, mucocutaneous telangiectasias, and systemic AVMs (e.g., pulmonary or cerebral), but not enchondromas or hemangiomas.
  • • Option D. Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Maffucci disease is defined by the coexistence of enchondromas and soft tissue hemangiomas , with phleboliths commonly visible on X-ray. Differentiation from Ollier disease : Ollier disease lacks soft tissue hemangiomas and associated phleboliths.
  • ➤ Maffucci disease is defined by the coexistence of enchondromas and soft tissue hemangiomas , with phleboliths commonly visible on X-ray.
  • ➤ Maffucci disease
  • ➤ enchondromas
  • ➤ soft tissue hemangiomas
  • ➤ Differentiation from Ollier disease : Ollier disease lacks soft tissue hemangiomas and associated phleboliths.
  • ➤ Differentiation from Ollier disease

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of abnormal uterine bleeding. The patient has had intermenstrual bleeding over the past 3 months. Speculum examination reveals a multiparous cervix with a small amount of bright red blood at the os and no visible cervical or vaginal lesions. FSH, TSH, and prolactin levels are normal. Urine pregnancy test is negative. USG is shown here. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's abnormal uterine bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Endometrial polyp

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The ultrasound image demonstrates the feeding vessel sign , which is characteristic of an endometrial polyp . Endometrial polyps are localized overgrowths of the endometrium and are a common cause of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB), especially intermenstrual bleeding.
  • • feeding vessel sign
  • • endometrial polyp
  • • Key features of the case:
  • • Key features of the case:
  • • Intermenstrual bleeding: This is the hallmark symptom of endometrial polyps. Normal hormonal levels: This rules out endocrine causes of AUB, such as dysfunctional uterine bleeding. Feeding vessel sign on USG: This Doppler feature is a specific finding for endometrial polyps, showing a single vascular stalk supplying the lesion.
  • • Intermenstrual bleeding: This is the hallmark symptom of endometrial polyps.
  • • Intermenstrual bleeding:
  • • Normal hormonal levels: This rules out endocrine causes of AUB, such as dysfunctional uterine bleeding.
  • • Normal hormonal levels:
  • • Feeding vessel sign on USG: This Doppler feature is a specific finding for endometrial polyps, showing a single vascular stalk supplying the lesion.
  • • Feeding vessel sign on USG:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Adenomyosis: Adenomyosis typically causes heavy, painful menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia or dysmenorrhea) and is associated with a bulky, tender uterus on examination. This presentation is not consistent with adenomyosis.
  • • Option A. Adenomyosis:
  • • heavy, painful menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia or dysmenorrhea)
  • • Option B. Endometrial hyperplasia: Endometrial hyperplasia is associated with prolonged or heavy bleeding rather than intermenstrual bleeding. It is often seen in women with unopposed estrogen exposure, such as those who are obese, have polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), or are taking estrogen therapy.
  • • Option B. Endometrial hyperplasia:
  • • prolonged or heavy bleeding
  • • Option D. Dysfunctional bleeding: Dysfunctional uterine bleeding (DUB) is a diagnosis of exclusion and occurs due to anovulatory cycles. It is unlikely in this case, as there is a structural abnormality (endometrial polyp) identified on imaging.
  • • Option D. Dysfunctional bleeding:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endometrial polyps are a common structural cause of abnormal uterine bleeding, particularly intermenstrual bleeding. The feeding vessel sign on Doppler ultrasound is a hallmark feature of endometrial polyps. Polyps are typically benign but can occasionally have malignant potential, especially in postmenopausal women.
  • ➤ Endometrial polyps are a common structural cause of abnormal uterine bleeding, particularly intermenstrual bleeding.
  • ➤ Endometrial polyps
  • ➤ The feeding vessel sign on Doppler ultrasound is a hallmark feature of endometrial polyps.
  • ➤ The feeding vessel sign on Doppler ultrasound is a hallmark feature of endometrial polyps.
  • ➤ Polyps are typically benign but can occasionally have malignant potential, especially in postmenopausal women.

questions.text: A newborn baby presents with continuous dribbling of saliva and choking while feeding. CXR is shown here. Identify the type of TEF:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The chest X-ray shows a coiled nasogastric tube in the esophageal pouch , indicating proximal esophageal atresia . Additionally, the presence of gas in the stomach confirms a distal tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) , which allows air to pass from the trachea into the stomach. This presentation is consistent with Type C TEF , the most common form of TEF, accounting for about 85-90% of cases.
  • • coiled nasogastric tube in the esophageal pouch
  • • proximal esophageal atresia
  • • gas in the stomach
  • • distal tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF)
  • • Type C TEF
  • • Key features of Type C TEF:
  • • Key features of Type C TEF:
  • • Proximal esophageal atresia: The esophagus ends in a blind pouch, causing the coiled nasogastric tube. Distal tracheoesophageal fistula: Allows air to enter the stomach, causing visible gas in the abdomen on X-ray. Symptoms include dribbling of saliva, choking during feeding, and respiratory distress due to aspiration.
  • • Proximal esophageal atresia: The esophagus ends in a blind pouch, causing the coiled nasogastric tube.
  • • Proximal esophageal atresia:
  • • Distal tracheoesophageal fistula: Allows air to enter the stomach, causing visible gas in the abdomen on X-ray.
  • • Distal tracheoesophageal fistula:
  • • Symptoms include dribbling of saliva, choking during feeding, and respiratory distress due to aspiration.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Type A (Pure esophageal atresia):
  • • Option A. Type A (Pure esophageal atresia):
  • • No fistula present. There is no air in the stomach because the esophagus does not connect to the trachea or stomach. This is ruled out due to the presence of gastric air in this case.
  • • No fistula present.
  • • There is no air in the stomach because the esophagus does not connect to the trachea or stomach.
  • • This is ruled out due to the presence of gastric air in this case.
  • • Option B. Type B (Proximal fistula with esophageal atresia):
  • • Option B. Type B (Proximal fistula with esophageal atresia):
  • • The proximal esophagus is connected to the trachea, and the distal esophagus is atretic. Air would not reach the stomach, ruling out this option.
  • • The proximal esophagus is connected to the trachea, and the distal esophagus is atretic.
  • • Air would not reach the stomach, ruling out this option.
  • • Option D. Type E (H-type fistula):
  • • Option D. Type E (H-type fistula):
  • • There is no esophageal atresia. Instead, there is a tracheoesophageal fistula, which allows communication between the esophagus and trachea. This type tends to present later in life with recurrent pneumonia or feeding difficulties, not as a neonatal emergency.
  • • There is no esophageal atresia. Instead, there is a tracheoesophageal fistula, which allows communication between the esophagus and trachea.
  • • This type tends to present later in life with recurrent pneumonia or feeding difficulties, not as a neonatal emergency.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type C TEF : Most common subtype, with proximal esophageal atresia and distal fistula. Key diagnostic clues : Coiled nasogastric tube in the esophageal pouch and gastric air on imaging. Management : Surgical repair is the definitive treatment.
  • ➤ Type C TEF : Most common subtype, with proximal esophageal atresia and distal fistula.
  • ➤ Type C TEF
  • ➤ Key diagnostic clues : Coiled nasogastric tube in the esophageal pouch and gastric air on imaging.
  • ➤ Key diagnostic clues
  • ➤ Management : Surgical repair is the definitive treatment.
  • ➤ Management

questions.text: All of the following are useful to reduce CIN in patients with diabetic nephropathy except:
questions.correct_answer: D. Doing CE-MRI instead of CECT
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Doing CE-MRI instead of CECT

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) is a potential complication of contrast administration in patients with renal impairment, such as diabetic nephropathy. Effective strategies to reduce the risk of CIN include using safer contrast agents, optimizing hydration, and stopping nephrotoxic medications.
  • • Doing CE-MRI instead of CECT:
  • • Doing CE-MRI instead of CECT:
  • • CE-MRI uses gadolinium-based contrast agents , which are not safer alternatives in patients with renal dysfunction. Gadolinium can cause nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF) , a severe systemic condition, especially in patients with impaired renal function. Hence, using CE-MRI with gadolinium is not an appropriate strategy to reduce CIN.
  • • CE-MRI uses gadolinium-based contrast agents , which are not safer alternatives in patients with renal dysfunction.
  • • gadolinium-based contrast agents
  • • Gadolinium can cause nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF) , a severe systemic condition, especially in patients with impaired renal function.
  • • nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF)
  • • Hence, using CE-MRI with gadolinium is not an appropriate strategy to reduce CIN.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Iodixanol:
  • • Option A. Iodixanol:
  • • Iodixanol is a non-ionic, dimeric iodinated contrast agent , which is considered the safest among iodinated contrasts. Non-ionic dimers, such as iodixanol, have a lower osmolality compared to ionic monomers, reducing the risk of nephrotoxicity. It is an effective strategy to reduce CIN risk.
  • • Iodixanol is a non-ionic, dimeric iodinated contrast agent , which is considered the safest among iodinated contrasts.
  • • non-ionic, dimeric iodinated contrast agent
  • • Non-ionic dimers, such as iodixanol, have a lower osmolality compared to ionic monomers, reducing the risk of nephrotoxicity.
  • • It is an effective strategy to reduce CIN risk.
  • • Option B. Hydration before contrast administration:
  • • Option B. Hydration before contrast administration:
  • • IV hydration is the most evidence-backed method to prevent CIN. Adequate hydration ensures proper renal perfusion and dilutes the contrast agent, minimizing nephrotoxicity.
  • • IV hydration is the most evidence-backed method to prevent CIN.
  • • IV hydration
  • • Adequate hydration ensures proper renal perfusion and dilutes the contrast agent, minimizing nephrotoxicity.
  • • Option C. Stopping nephrotoxic drugs before contrast:
  • • Option C. Stopping nephrotoxic drugs before contrast:
  • • Discontinuing nephrotoxic medications (e.g., NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, metformin) before contrast administration reduces the burden on the kidneys and helps prevent CIN.
  • • Discontinuing nephrotoxic medications (e.g., NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, metformin) before contrast administration reduces the burden on the kidneys and helps prevent CIN.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CIN prevention strategies include: Using low-osmolality or iso-osmolality contrast agents (e.g., iodixanol). Hydration before and after contrast administration. questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with sudden onset breathlessness and a sharp pain in his chest after a road traffic accident. His BP is 85/69mm Hg and HR is 110bpm. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the next step for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Insert IV cannula and start IV fluids

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Needle thoracostomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The chest X-ray reveals a right-sided pneumothorax , evident from the hyperlucent lung field with no visible lung markings and a collapsed lung. The patient is clinically unstable, with hypotension (BP 85/69 mmHg) and tachycardia (HR 110 bpm). This presentation is indicative of a tension pneumothorax , a life-threatening condition that requires immediate decompression .

  • • tension pneumothorax
  • • immediate decompression
  • • Management Steps:
  • • Management Steps:
  • • Needle thoracostomy (immediate decompression): Insert a needle into the second intercostal space at the midclavicular line to relieve the tension pneumothorax. Follow up with ICD insertion (intercostal drain) for definitive management.
  • • Needle thoracostomy (immediate decompression): Insert a needle into the second intercostal space at the midclavicular line to relieve the tension pneumothorax.

  • • Follow up with ICD insertion (intercostal drain) for definitive management.
  • • ICD insertion
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:

Management of the life-threatening condition takes precedence.
  • • Option A. eFAST:
  • • Option B. Insert IV cannula and start IV fluids: The patient is in obstructive shock , not hypovolemic shock. IV fluids are not the immediate treatment for obstructive shock caused by a tension pneumothorax. Decompression of the pneumothorax must be performed first.
  • • Option B. Insert IV cannula and start IV fluids:
  • • obstructive shock
  • • Option D. ICD insertion: ICD (intercostal drain) placement is the definitive treatment for a pneumothorax. However, in this case, needle thoracostomy is the immediate next step to stabilize the patient before inserting an ICD.

  • • needle thoracostomy is the immediate next step

Signs on X-ray : Hyperlucent lung field, absent lung markings, and mediastinal shift away from the affected side.

questions.text: The following appearance in IVP is caused by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ureterocele

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows an adder head appearance on an intravenous pyelogram (IVP), which is characteristic of a ureterocele . A ureterocele is a congenital abnormality where the distal ureter balloons into the bladder, causing a cystic dilation. This appearance is due to the dilated ureter at the vesicoureteral junction being filled with contrast and appearing like a cobra head or adder head.

  • • ureterocele
  • • Key features of ureterocele:
  • • Key features of ureterocele:
  • • Commonly associated with duplication anomalies of the urinary system. Can cause obstruction or reflux, leading to symptoms such as urinary tract infections or hydronephrosis. Diagnosed on IVP or ultrasound, where the characteristic "adder head" or "cobra head" sign is seen.
  • • Commonly associated with duplication anomalies of the urinary system.

  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Horseshoe kidney:
  • • Option B. Horseshoe kidney:
  • • This congenital anomaly involves the fusion of the lower poles of the kidneys. IVP in horseshoe kidney shows a "U-shaped" appearance of the kidneys due to their abnormal position and fusion. This does not match the adder head appearance in this case.
  • • This congenital anomaly involves the fusion of the lower poles of the kidneys.
  • • IVP in horseshoe kidney shows a "U-shaped" appearance of the kidneys due to their abnormal position and fusion.
  • • This does not match the adder head appearance in this case.
  • • Option C. Retroperitoneal fibrosis:
  • • Option C. Retroperitoneal fibrosis:
  • • This is characterized by fibrosis around the retroperitoneal structures, leading to ureteral obstruction. On IVP, this would present as medial deviation of the ureters, but not the adder head appearance.
  • • This is characterized by fibrosis around the retroperitoneal structures, leading to ureteral obstruction.

  • • Option D. Posterior urethral valve:
  • • Option D. Posterior urethral valve:

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 15-year-old male with pain and swelling gradually increasing over 4 months at the upper end of tibia. What is the likely diagnosis?

  • • sclerotic rim

questions.text: A 45-year-old male reports to the OPD with mild abdominal discomfort and fever, which gradually escalated to severe, crampy abdominal pain. He has lost approximately 15kg over the last six months. Identify the imaging modality performed:

questions.text: A 45-yr-old male underwent a RTA. He is unconscious with a GCS of 6. CT shows a few tiny hyperdense foci. A special MRI sequence is shown here. What is the diagnosis?

SWI sequence : Demonstrates multiple punctate hemorrhages, a classic feature of DAI. Clinical correlation: DAI is a common cause of unconsciousness and prolonged coma following traumatic brain injury.
  • • History of trauma (RTA) with low GCS , as seen in this case.

  • • low GCS
  • • CT findings : Tiny hyperdense foci suggest microhemorrhages, often confirmed by MRI.

  • • SWI sequence : Demonstrates multiple punctate hemorrhages, a classic feature of DAI.

  • • Other Options:

  • • Option A. Contusion: Cerebral contusions appear as hyperdense regions with surrounding edema on CT. While contusions can occur after trauma, they are localized injuries, unlike the diffuse microhemorrhages seen in DAI.

  • • Option C. Subdural hematoma (SDH): SDH appears as a crescent-shaped hyperdensity along the brain's convexity on CT. It is a collection of blood between the dura mater and the brain and does not present with diffuse punctate hemorrhages on MRI.

  • • Option D. Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH): SAH shows hyperdensity in the subarachnoid spaces on CT. On MRI, it appears as areas of high intensity on FLAIR imaging, not the black dots seen in this SWI image.

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. His vitals are stable. He has a history of peptic ulcer disease. All of the following should be done except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Barium meal.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient has a history of peptic ulcer disease and presents with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The chest X-ray provided shows air under the diaphragm, indicating a perforated viscus, likely due to peptic ulcer perforation. Perforation is a surgical emergency requiring immediate intervention.
  • • Management steps:
  • • Management steps:
  • • Exploratory laparotomy is the definitive treatment to locate and repair the perforation. Resuscitation is essential for stabilizing the patient (e.g., IV fluids, antibiotics). CECT with oral contrast can be used to confirm the diagnosis or evaluate the extent of the perforation if necessary.
  • • Exploratory laparotomy is the definitive treatment to locate and repair the perforation.
  • • Exploratory laparotomy
  • • Resuscitation is essential for stabilizing the patient (e.g., IV fluids, antibiotics).
  • • Resuscitation
  • • CECT with oral contrast can be used to confirm the diagnosis or evaluate the extent of the perforation if necessary.
  • • CECT with oral contrast
  • • However, barium meal studies are contraindicated in cases of gastrointestinal perforation. The leakage of barium into the peritoneal cavity can cause severe chemical peritonitis, which worsens the clinical condition and complicates treatment.
  • • barium meal studies
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. CECT with oral contrast: This investigation is safe and can be performed in cases of gastrointestinal perforation. Iodinated oral contrast is preferred and does not pose a risk of chemical peritonitis.
  • • Option A. CECT with oral contrast:
  • • Option B. Exploratory laparotomy: This is the definitive treatment in cases of gastrointestinal perforation. It allows for direct visualization and repair of the perforated site.
  • • Option B. Exploratory laparotomy:
  • • Option D. Resuscitation: Stabilization of the patient through IV fluids, antibiotics, and management of any electrolyte imbalances is a critical initial step in preparation for surgery.
  • • Option D. Resuscitation:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Barium studies are contraindicated in gastrointestinal perforation due to the risk of chemical peritonitis. Management of perforation involves resuscitation, imaging (if needed), and definitive surgical repair. Air under the diaphragm on X-ray is a key finding for perforated viscus.

  • ➤ Management of perforation involves resuscitation, imaging (if needed), and definitive surgical repair.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with subacute knee pain and swelling. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Baker’s cyst

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The MRI image shows a fluid-filled lesion located in the popliteal fossa with a characteristic "speech bubble" morphology, which is indicative of a Baker’s cyst . Baker’s cysts, also known as popliteal cysts, are formed when fluid accumulates in a bursa located between the semimembranosus and medial gastrocnemius muscles. This condition is often associated with underlying joint pathology such as osteoarthritis or inflammatory arthritis, which can increase synovial fluid production.
  • • Baker’s cyst
  • • semimembranosus
  • • medial gastrocnemius
  • • The patient’s presentation of subacute knee pain and swelling aligns with the clinical manifestations of a Baker’s cyst. These cysts may rupture in some cases, causing sudden pain and swelling that can mimic deep vein thrombosis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Deep vein thrombosis: DVT can cause unilateral swelling and pain in the leg, but it does not present as a well-defined cystic lesion in the popliteal fossa on imaging. Diagnosis is confirmed with Doppler ultrasound, not MRI.
  • • Option B.
  • • Deep vein thrombosis:
  • • Option C . Juvenile idiopathic arthritis: This condition primarily affects children and adolescents, typically younger than 16 years old, and is characterized by joint pain and swelling in multiple joints. The MRI findings do not support this diagnosis in this 25-year-old patient.
  • • Option C
  • • Juvenile idiopathic arthritis:
  • • Option D . ACL avulsion: ACL avulsion is associated with trauma and is characterized by acute knee pain and instability rather than subacute swelling. Imaging would typically show disruption of the ligament or associated bony avulsion, which is not seen here.
  • • Option D
  • • ACL avulsion:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Baker’s cyst is a fluid-filled swelling in the popliteal fossa, located between the medial gastrocnemius and semimembranosus muscles. It is commonly associated with underlying joint conditions like osteoarthritis or inflammatory arthritis. MRI imaging is the most definitive modality for diagnosing a Baker’s cyst.
  • ➤ Baker’s cyst is a fluid-filled swelling in the popliteal fossa, located between the medial gastrocnemius and semimembranosus muscles.

  • ➤ It is commonly associated with underlying joint conditions like osteoarthritis or inflammatory arthritis.
  • ➤ MRI imaging is the most definitive modality for diagnosing a Baker’s cyst.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is admitted for fever, cough, and malaise for the past two days. She has no history of sick contacts, and all her immunizations are up to date. Her leukocyte count is 21,000/mm with 7% band forms. Upright chest x-ray findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely location of the pathologic process in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Right upper lobe

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The chest X-ray provided shows a consolidation in the right upper lung field, which is indicated by increased opacity and loss of normal aeration. Consolidation occurs when alveoli become filled with fluid, pus, or other material, often seen in bacterial pneumonia.
  • • This patient’s symptoms (fever, cough, malaise) and elevated leukocyte count with bandemia strongly suggest an infectious etiology, such as pneumonia. Right upper lobe involvement is commonly associated with bacterial infections such as those caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae .
  • • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Left lower lung lobe: Consolidation in the left lower lung lobe would appear as an opacity at the base of the lung, often silhouetting the diaphragm. There is no radiographic evidence in this image supporting involvement of the left lower lobe.
  • • Option A. Left lower lung lobe:
  • • Option B. Left pleural space: Pathologies in the pleural space, such as pleural effusion, would present as a homogeneous opacity with obliteration of the costophrenic angle or layering of fluid. No findings in the X-ray indicate a pleural space abnormality.
  • • Option B. Left pleural space:
  • • Option C. Right middle lung lobe: Consolidation in the right middle lobe would typically obscure the right heart border on a frontal view. The opacity in this image is located in the upper lung field and does not involve the middle lobe.
  • • Option C. Right middle lung lobe:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Consolidation in the right upper lung lobe is characterized by opacity on chest X-ray due to alveolar filling. Bacterial pneumonia should be suspected in patients with fever, cough, leukocytosis, and focal lung findings.
  • ➤ Consolidation in the right upper lung lobe is characterized by opacity on chest X-ray due to alveolar filling.
  • ➤ right upper lung lobe
  • ➤ Bacterial pneumonia should be suspected in patients with fever, cough, leukocytosis, and focal lung findings.
  • ➤ Bacterial pneumonia

questions.text: A 30-year-old with motor vehicle accident presented to the causality. His vitals are stable, but he is unable to pass urine. He has blood at the urethral meatus. An RGU was performed as shown below. What is the most likely site of urethral injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bulbar urethra

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The RGU image reveals leakage of contrast in the region of the bulbar urethra, confirming a diagnosis of bulbar urethral rupture. The bulbar urethra is a part of the anterior urethra and is commonly injured in trauma due to straddle injuries or blunt perineal trauma, which are typical mechanisms in motor vehicle accidents.
  • • This patient’s inability to pass urine and the presence of blood at the urethral meatus are classic clinical signs of urethral injury. The stable vitals and imaging findings further support the diagnosis of isolated bulbar urethral injury, without evidence of pelvic fractures (which are more often associated with posterior urethral injuries like membranous urethral rupture).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Penile urethra: The penile urethra is distal to the bulbar urethra and runs through the shaft of the penis. It is less commonly injured in trauma and would show contrast extravasation located more distally on RGU imaging, which is not seen in this case.
  • • Option A. Penile urethra:
  • • Option B. Membranous urethra: The membranous urethra is part of the posterior urethra and lies proximal to the bulbar urethra. Membranous urethral injuries are typically associated with pelvic fractures and high-riding prostate on examination, neither of which is present here.
  • • Option B. Membranous urethra:
  • • Option C. Spongy urethra: The spongy urethra refers to the portion of the urethra within the corpus spongiosum, including the penile urethra and bulbar urethra. While the bulbar urethra is part of the spongy urethra, this answer is too broad and lacks the specificity needed for this case.
  • • Option C. Spongy urethra:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The bulbar urethra , part of the anterior urethra, is commonly injured in trauma such as motor vehicle accidents or straddle injuries. Classic signs of urethral injury include inability to void, blood at the urethral meatus, and imaging evidence of contrast extravasation on RGU. Posterior urethral injuries are more commonly associated with pelvic fractures, while anterior urethral injuries, like bulbar urethral trauma, occur in isolated trauma.
  • ➤ The bulbar urethra , part of the anterior urethra, is commonly injured in trauma such as motor vehicle accidents or straddle injuries.
  • ➤ bulbar urethra
  • ➤ Classic signs of urethral injury include inability to void, blood at the urethral meatus, and imaging evidence of contrast extravasation on RGU.
  • ➤ Posterior urethral injuries are more commonly associated with pelvic fractures, while anterior urethral injuries, like bulbar urethral trauma, occur in isolated trauma.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents, who report that he has been having episodes of cyanosis, especially during feeding and crying. The baby was born at full term without any complications during the pregnancy or delivery. On physical examination, the pediatrician notices that the infant has clubbing of his fingers and toes and a harsh systolic murmur heard best at the upper left sternal border. His chest radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The chest X-ray demonstrates a boot-shaped heart , which is a classic finding in Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) . TOF is the most common cyanotic congenital heart defect and is characterized by four components:
  • • boot-shaped heart
  • • Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)
  • • Right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO) Ventricular septal defect (VSD) Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH) Overriding aorta
  • • Right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO)
  • • Right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO)
  • • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)
  • • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)
  • • Overriding aorta
  • • Overriding aorta
  • • The clinical presentation of cyanosis during feeding or crying (tet spells), clubbing of fingers and toes, and a harsh systolic murmur best heard at the upper left sternal border (caused by RVOTO) further supports the diagnosis.
  • • In TOF, reduced blood flow to the lungs due to RVOTO leads to systemic desaturation and cyanosis. The "boot-shaped heart" is due to right ventricular hypertrophy seen on radiographic imaging.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ebstein's anomaly: This is a congenital heart defect involving abnormal downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle. It may present with cyanosis but is associated with an enlarged, globular heart on chest X-ray, not a boot-shaped heart.
  • • Option A. Ebstein's anomaly:
  • • Option B. Transposition of great arteries (TGA): TGA is characterized by cyanosis shortly after birth due to the parallel circulation of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. Chest X-ray typically shows an "egg-on-a-string" appearance, not a boot-shaped heart.
  • • Option B. Transposition of great arteries (TGA):
  • • Option D. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC): In TAPVC, all pulmonary veins drain into the systemic venous circulation. Cyanosis is present, but chest X-ray findings typically show cardiomegaly with increased pulmonary vascular markings, not the boot-shaped heart seen in TOF.
  • • Option D. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most common cyanotic congenital heart defect. Cyanosis during exertion or crying, clubbing, and a harsh systolic murmur at the left sternal border are classic features of TOF. A boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray is a hallmark finding due to right ventricular hypertrophy.
  • ➤ Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most common cyanotic congenital heart defect.
  • ➤ Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)
  • ➤ Cyanosis during exertion or crying, clubbing, and a harsh systolic murmur at the left sternal border are classic features of TOF.
  • ➤ A boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray is a hallmark finding due to right ventricular hypertrophy.
  • ➤ boot-shaped heart

questions.text: Which of the following contrast media is ionic monomer?

Non-Ionic Monomers: These are non-ionic and consist of a single molecule. Their names usually end in "-ol," such as iohexol (commonly used in practice under the trade name Omnipaque). Non-Ionic Dimers: These are non-ionic and consist of two molecules joined together. The example to remember is iodixanol (trade name Visipaque). Ionic Dimers: These are ionic and consist of two molecules joined together. The example to remember is ioxaglate .

  • • Option B. Omniscan: An MRI contrast agent, not relevant for ionic monomer classification.

questions.text: Indications of biopsy in the pathology shown are all except:
questions.correct_answer: D. Cold abscess without neurological deficit
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cold abscess without neurological deficit

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The MRI image shows features consistent with Pott’s spine , also known as spinal tuberculosis. This pathology involves paradiscal involvement , formation of abscesses, and vertebral destruction. A biopsy is indicated in cases where diagnostic uncertainty or drug resistance exists or when neurological complications are present.
  • • Pott’s spine
  • • paradiscal involvement
  • • A cold abscess without neurological deficit does not necessitate a biopsy, as the diagnosis of spinal tuberculosis can often be established clinically and radiologically. Biopsy is reserved for cases with complicating factors to guide further management.
  • • cold abscess without neurological deficit
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Drug resistance: Biopsy is necessary to identify the organism and determine resistance patterns to guide appropriate antimicrobial therapy.
  • • Option A. Drug resistance:
  • • Option B. Unclear diagnosis: Biopsy is warranted when radiological findings do not conclusively point to tuberculosis or other conditions need to be ruled out (e.g., malignancy).
  • • Option B. Unclear diagnosis:
  • • Option C. Conus syndrome: Neurological involvement, such as conus medullaris or cauda equina syndrome, often requires biopsy to confirm the diagnosis and guide further management.
  • • Option C. Conus syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Biopsy in Pott’s spine is indicated in cases of drug resistance, unclear diagnosis, or neurological involvement. A cold abscess without neurological deficit does not require biopsy if the diagnosis is clear based on clinical and imaging findings.
  • ➤ Biopsy in Pott’s spine is indicated in cases of drug resistance, unclear diagnosis, or neurological involvement.

questions.text: 35-year-old male with fever post-allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) three weeks ago for acute myeloid leukemia (AML). HRCT is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 46-year-old male with back ache, morning stiffness and reddening of eyes. X- ray of the patient is given below. Identify the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The X-ray demonstrates the "bamboo spine" appearance, which is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) . Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the axial skeleton, including the sacroiliac joints and spine. Fusion of the vertebrae results in a rigid spine, producing the classic radiologic sign of a bamboo spine.

  • • ankylosing spondylitis (AS)
  • • Clinical features such as back pain , morning stiffness , and eye inflammation (e.g., uveitis) further support the diagnosis. AS typically affects younger individuals, with symptoms often starting in the second or third decade of life.

  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis primarily affects the small joints of the hands and feet and is associated with symmetrical joint involvement and soft-tissue swelling. It does not produce the bamboo spine appearance.
  • • Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis:
  • • Option B. Ochronosis: Ochronosis is associated with deposition of homogentisic acid in connective tissues, leading to calcification of intervertebral discs. It does not cause bamboo spine but may produce disc space narrowing and calcification.
  • • Option B. Ochronosis:
  • • Option D. DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis): DISH is characterized by flowing calcifications and ossifications along the anterior longitudinal ligament, typically sparing the sacroiliac joints. It does not result in the bamboo spine appearance.
  • • Option D. DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ankylosing spondylitis is characterized by the bamboo spine appearance due to vertebral fusion. Clinical features include back pain, morning stiffness, and extra-articular manifestations like uveitis.

questions.text: FDG-PET negative tumor is:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male underwent NCCT abdomen for suspected renal calculi. An incidental finding was noted in the liver. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hydatid cyst

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The NCCT (non-contrast CT) image shows a calcified lesion in the liver , which is characteristic of a hydatid cyst in its later stages. Hydatid cysts are caused by infection with Echinococcus granulosus or Echinococcus multilocularis. Over time, these cysts can calcify, making them appear as hyperdense (white) lesions on non-contrast CT.

  • • hydatid cyst
  • • Key points for hydatid cyst diagnosis:
  • • Calcification is a hallmark of hydatid cysts in late-stage disease. Other liver lesions (e.g., hepatocellular carcinoma, fibronodular hyperplasia, or abscesses) do not typically calcify. Hydatid cysts may have a cystic appearance with internal septations or calcification on imaging.
  • • Calcification is a hallmark of hydatid cysts in late-stage disease. Other liver lesions (e.g., hepatocellular carcinoma, fibronodular hyperplasia, or abscesses) do not typically calcify.
  • • Hydatid cysts may have a cystic appearance with internal septations or calcification on imaging.

  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC): HCC typically presents as a vascular lesion on contrast-enhanced imaging (CECT or MRI) with arterial enhancement and venous washout. Calcification is rare and not a typical feature.
  • • Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC):
  • • Option B. Fibronodular hyperplasia (FNH): FNH appears as a hypervascular lesion with a central scar on contrast-enhanced imaging. It does not calcify, and incidental findings of FNH are seen on contrast studies, not non-contrast CT.
  • • Option B. Fibronodular hyperplasia (FNH):
  • • Option C. Liver abscess: Liver abscesses show a characteristic ring-enhancing appearance on contrast-enhanced CT (CECT), with a thickened, enhancing wall and a hypodense center representing pus. They do not calcify and would not appear as a hyperdense lesion on NCCT.

  • • ring-enhancing appearance

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented in OPD with recurrent respiratory infections and thickened sputum. Chest X-ray is shown. Patient also had steatorrhea since birth. What is the likely defect?

  • • Cystic fibrosis is caused by mutations in the CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene located on chromosome 7 . The most common mutation is the ΔF508 (delta F508) deletion , which results in a misfolded CFTR protein that cannot reach the cell surface, causing defective chloride and water transport across epithelial cells. This leads to thick mucus, chronic infections, and malabsorption due to pancreatic insufficiency.
  • • CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator)
  • • chromosome 7
  • • ΔF508 (delta F508) deletion
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:

  • • Option B. F510 Deletion:
  • • Option C. P508 Frameshift Mutation: Frameshift mutations in the CFTR gene are rare, and P508 frameshift mutation is not a known mutation for CF.
  • • Option C. P508 Frameshift Mutation:
  • • P508 frameshift mutation
  • • Option D. P510 Frameshift Mutation: Similar to option C, this is not a recognized mutation associated with cystic fibrosis.
  • • Option D. P510 Frameshift Mutation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystic fibrosis is most commonly caused by the ΔF508 deletion in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7. Key features include recurrent respiratory infections, bronchiectasis, thickened mucus, and steatorrhea due to pancreatic insufficiency. Radiologic findings like cystic bronchiectasis and clinical features are crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text: A new born male baby presented with congestive heart failure. Following radiological finding was noted the mostly likely diagnosis:

questions.text: Which of the following is most radioresistant phase of cell cycle?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) S

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The S phase (synthesis phase) of the cell cycle is the most radioresistant phase. This is because, during the S phase, DNA replication occurs, and the high activity of DNA repair mechanisms in this phase protects cells from radiation-induced damage.
  • • S phase (synthesis phase)
  • • radioresistant
  • • Key points:
  • • Radioresistance : Refers to the ability of cells to withstand the effects of ionizing radiation. S phase : Active DNA repair during replication makes this phase the most resistant to radiation.
  • • Radioresistance : Refers to the ability of cells to withstand the effects of ionizing radiation.
  • • Radioresistance
  • • S phase : Active DNA repair during replication makes this phase the most resistant to radiation.
  • • S phase
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. G1: G1 is moderately radiosensitive. Damage in this phase can cause arrest at the G1/S checkpoint.
  • • Option A. G1:
  • • Option B. G2: The G2 phase is more radiosensitive because the cell prepares for mitosis, and DNA repair mechanisms are less effective compared to the S phase.
  • • Option B. G2:
  • • Option D. M (Mitosis): The M phase is the most radiosensitive phase, as the chromosomes are condensed and most vulnerable to radiation damage.
  • • Option D. M (Mitosis):
  • • radiosensitive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The S phase is the most radioresistant due to the high efficiency of DNA repair mechanisms during DNA synthesis. In contrast, the M phase is the most radiosensitive , as condensed chromosomes are less capable of repair.
  • ➤ S phase
  • ➤ radioresistant
  • ➤ M phase
  • ➤ radiosensitive

Ans. A) A

  • • Action: Hip flexion.

  • • C and D (Gluteus muscles):

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has come with sudden onset of chest pain and his CT scan shows the following picture. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aortic dissection

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The CT scan demonstrates an aortic dissection , characterized by a clear intimal flap separating the true and false lumens in the ascending aorta . This condition occurs when there is a tear in the intima of the aorta, allowing blood to flow between the layers of the vessel wall.
  • • aortic dissection
  • • intimal flap
  • • ascending aorta
  • • Key features:
  • • Sudden onset chest pain : Tearing or ripping pain radiating to the back is characteristic. Imaging findings : A contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) shows the intimal flap , dividing the aorta into true and false lumens. Classification (Stanford): Stanford A : Involves the ascending aorta (as seen in this case). Requires urgent surgery . Stanford B : Involves only the descending aorta. Managed medically unless complications arise.
  • • Sudden onset chest pain : Tearing or ripping pain radiating to the back is characteristic.
  • • Sudden onset chest pain
  • • Imaging findings : A contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) shows the intimal flap , dividing the aorta into true and false lumens.
  • • Imaging findings
  • • intimal flap
  • • Classification (Stanford): Stanford A : Involves the ascending aorta (as seen in this case). Requires urgent surgery . Stanford B : Involves only the descending aorta. Managed medically unless complications arise.
  • • Classification (Stanford):
  • • Stanford A : Involves the ascending aorta (as seen in this case). Requires urgent surgery . Stanford B : Involves only the descending aorta. Managed medically unless complications arise.
  • • Stanford A : Involves the ascending aorta (as seen in this case). Requires urgent surgery .
  • • Stanford A
  • • urgent surgery
  • • Stanford B : Involves only the descending aorta. Managed medically unless complications arise.
  • • Stanford B
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pulmonary embolism: Pulmonary embolism appears as a filling defect in the pulmonary arteries on CECT (saddle embolism or segmental branch emboli). This is not seen here.
  • • Option A. Pulmonary embolism:
  • • Option C. Aortic aneurysm: An aneurysm is a localized dilation of the aorta. It lacks the intimal flap seen in dissection and typically appears as a uniform enlargement of the vessel.
  • • Option C. Aortic aneurysm:
  • • Option D. Myocardial infarction: MI does not produce findings on CT unless complications like wall rupture or aneurysm are present. Diagnosis of MI is typically based on ECG and cardiac biomarkers.
  • • Option D. Myocardial infarction:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aortic dissection is a medical emergency. CECT is the diagnostic modality of choice, revealing an intimal flap . Management depends on the Stanford classification :
  • ➤ Aortic dissection
  • ➤ intimal flap
  • ➤ Stanford classification
  • ➤ Stanford A : Urgent surgical intervention. Stanford B : Medical management with blood pressure control (e.g., IV beta-blockers like esmolol).
  • ➤ Stanford A : Urgent surgical intervention.
  • ➤ Stanford A
  • ➤ Stanford B : Medical management with blood pressure control (e.g., IV beta-blockers like esmolol).
  • ➤ Stanford B

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented with a history of road traffic accident. The axial CT image is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Extradural Hemorrhage

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The CT scan demonstrates a biconvex, lens-shaped hyperdense collection on the axial view, characteristic of an Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH) .
  • • biconvex, lens-shaped hyperdense collection
  • • Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH)
  • • Key features include:
  • • Appearance: Lens-shaped or "idli-shaped" hyperdense hematoma, confined by the sutures of the skull. Cause: Most often associated with trauma, causing rupture of the middle meningeal artery . This is commonly due to a skull fracture at the pterion , where the middle meningeal artery lies beneath. Timing: Hyperdense appearance suggests acute EDH , as chronic EDH would appear hypodense.
  • • Appearance: Lens-shaped or "idli-shaped" hyperdense hematoma, confined by the sutures of the skull.
  • • Appearance:
  • • Cause: Most often associated with trauma, causing rupture of the middle meningeal artery . This is commonly due to a skull fracture at the pterion , where the middle meningeal artery lies beneath.
  • • Cause:
  • • middle meningeal artery
  • • pterion
  • • Timing: Hyperdense appearance suggests acute EDH , as chronic EDH would appear hypodense.
  • • Timing:
  • • acute EDH
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH): SDH typically appears as a crescent-shaped hematoma that crosses suture lines but is confined by the dural reflections. It is not biconvex like EDH.
  • • Option B. Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH):
  • • Option C. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH): SAH appears as hyperdense blood within the sulci, cisterns, or ventricles, and is not localized to the extra-axial space.
  • • Option C. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH):
  • • Option D. Intraventricular Hemorrhage (IVH): IVH presents as hyperdensity within the ventricles and is often associated with diffuse intracranial hemorrhages. It does not produce a biconvex shape.
  • • Option D. Intraventricular Hemorrhage (IVH):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of head trauma, a biconvex, hyperdense collection on CT is highly indicative of an Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH) , most commonly due to rupture of the middle meningeal artery .
  • ➤ biconvex, hyperdense collection on CT
  • ➤ Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH)
  • ➤ middle meningeal artery

questions.text: Which of the following shows the skull Xray appearance as shown in the image:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Thalassemia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The X-ray image demonstrates a "hair-on-end" or "crew-cut" appearance , which is characteristic of hemolytic anemias , particularly thalassemia . This appearance results from extramedullary hematopoiesis , where the bone marrow expands in response to chronic anemia, leading to vertical striations in the skull bones.
  • • "hair-on-end" or "crew-cut" appearance
  • • hemolytic anemias
  • • thalassemia
  • • extramedullary hematopoiesis
  • • Key findings for thalassemia :
  • • thalassemia
  • • Chronic anemia stimulates extramedullary hematopoiesis , causing marrow expansion and this characteristic radiographic finding. Often seen in conditions like thalassemia or sickle cell anemia where severe hemolysis occurs.
  • • Chronic anemia stimulates extramedullary hematopoiesis , causing marrow expansion and this characteristic radiographic finding.
  • • extramedullary hematopoiesis
  • • Often seen in conditions like thalassemia or sickle cell anemia where severe hemolysis occurs.
  • • thalassemia
  • • sickle cell anemia
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Raised ICP (Increased Intracranial Pressure): In raised ICP, the skull X-ray may show a copper-beaten appearance , characterized by convolutional markings from the brain's gyri and sulci imprinted on the inner table of the skull.
  • • Option A. Raised ICP (Increased Intracranial Pressure):
  • • copper-beaten appearance
  • • Option B. Multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma typically shows "raindrop skull" or "punched-out lesions" , which are well-defined lytic lesions throughout the skull.
  • • Option B. Multiple myeloma:
  • • "raindrop skull" or "punched-out lesions"
  • • Option C. Megaloblastic anemia: Megaloblastic anemia does not lead to this X-ray appearance. It is associated with other features such as glossitis, macrocytic anemia, and hypersegmented neutrophils on a peripheral blood smear, but no distinctive skull findings.
  • • Option C. Megaloblastic anemia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hair-on-end or crew-cut appearance on skull X-ray is a hallmark of hemolytic anemias , especially thalassemia . This is caused by marrow hyperplasia due to chronic hemolysis and anemia.
  • ➤ hair-on-end or crew-cut appearance
  • ➤ hemolytic anemias
  • ➤ thalassemia

questions.text: In which of the following is MRI better than CT:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pancoast tumor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • MRI is particularly useful in evaluating Pancoast tumors because these tumors are located at the lung apex and often invade adjacent structures, such as the brachial plexus , subclavian vessels , and spine . MRI provides superior soft tissue contrast compared to CT, making it better for assessing nerve involvement and extension into adjacent structures.
  • • Pancoast tumors
  • • brachial plexus
  • • subclavian vessels
  • • spine
  • • nerve involvement
  • • While CT is the modality of choice for initial evaluation and staging of most lung tumors, MRI is specifically indicated when there is suspected invasion of soft tissue, neural, or vascular structures, as in the case of Pancoast tumors.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Adenocarcinoma lung: CT is the primary imaging modality for adenocarcinoma of the lung, providing excellent detail for lung parenchymal and mediastinal structures. MRI does not offer significant advantages in these cases.
  • • Option A. Adenocarcinoma lung:
  • • Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma lung: Similar to adenocarcinoma, CT is preferred for evaluating squamous cell carcinoma. MRI is not routinely used unless there is suspicion of mediastinal or spinal involvement.
  • • Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma lung:
  • • Option C. Mesothelioma: CT is typically preferred for assessing pleural thickening and involvement in mesothelioma. MRI may provide additional information in selected cases, but it is not superior to CT for routine evaluation.
  • • Option C. Mesothelioma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MRI is superior to CT in evaluating Pancoast tumors , especially for assessing nerve, soft tissue, or vascular involvement .
  • ➤ MRI is superior to CT in evaluating Pancoast tumors , especially for assessing nerve, soft tissue, or vascular involvement .
  • ➤ Pancoast tumors
  • ➤ nerve, soft tissue, or vascular involvement

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presented with acute onset pain in right limb. An investigation was performed. What is the name of the investigation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ultrasound doppler

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image depicts a triphasic waveform , which is characteristic of normal arterial blood flow in the extremities. This investigation is an ultrasound Doppler , a non-invasive diagnostic tool used to evaluate blood flow in arteries and veins.
  • • triphasic waveform
  • • ultrasound Doppler
  • • Key features of triphasic waveforms:
  • • Forward flow in systole: Indicates the main phase of blood flow during ventricular contraction. Brief reverse flow in early diastole: Due to elastic recoil of the vessel wall. Forward flow in late diastole: Represents compliance of the arterial system.
  • • Forward flow in systole: Indicates the main phase of blood flow during ventricular contraction.
  • • Forward flow in systole:
  • • Brief reverse flow in early diastole: Due to elastic recoil of the vessel wall.
  • • Brief reverse flow in early diastole:
  • • Forward flow in late diastole: Represents compliance of the arterial system.
  • • Forward flow in late diastole:
  • • In this case, the ultrasound Doppler is used to assess the vascular status of the limb in a patient presenting with acute limb pain, likely due to arterial occlusion or insufficiency.
  • • ultrasound Doppler
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Digital subtraction angiography: This is an invasive imaging technique used to evaluate blood vessels by injecting contrast dye. It is not shown in this image and is typically reserved for detailed vascular studies or interventions.
  • • Option A. Digital subtraction angiography:
  • • Option C. Plethysmography: Plethysmography measures changes in blood volume within an organ or limb, but it does not provide direct visualization of waveforms like Doppler imaging does.
  • • Option C. Plethysmography:
  • • Option D. MR Angiography: Magnetic resonance angiography visualizes blood vessels using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). It does not generate real-time waveforms as shown in the image.
  • • Option D. MR Angiography:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ultrasound Doppler is the investigation of choice for evaluating arterial blood flow in the extremities. A triphasic waveform indicates normal arterial flow, whereas alterations in the waveform (e.g., monophasic or biphasic) suggest arterial disease.
  • ➤ Ultrasound Doppler is the investigation of choice for evaluating arterial blood flow in the extremities.
  • ➤ Ultrasound Doppler
  • ➤ A triphasic waveform indicates normal arterial flow, whereas alterations in the waveform (e.g., monophasic or biphasic) suggest arterial disease.
  • ➤ triphasic waveform

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with a pulsatile supraclavicular neck mass. What is the most appropriate next investigation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Doppler USG

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The presence of a pulsatile supraclavicular neck mass raises suspicion for a vascular etiology, such as an aneurysm , arteriovenous malformation, or other vascular abnormality. The next appropriate investigation is Doppler ultrasound , a non-invasive, readily available, and effective tool for assessing vascular lesions. Doppler ultrasound can confirm whether the mass is vascular in origin and provide information about blood flow characteristics.
  • • pulsatile supraclavicular neck mass
  • • aneurysm
  • • Doppler ultrasound
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. CT Angio + Percutaneous intervention: CT angiography is a more advanced imaging modality that provides detailed vascular anatomy. However, it is not the first-line investigation. If Doppler confirms a vascular lesion, CT angio may be considered for further characterization or intervention.
  • • Option B. CT Angio + Percutaneous intervention:
  • • Option C. Oral Antibiotics x 7 days: Antibiotics are used to treat infections, but a pulsatile mass suggests a vascular cause rather than an infectious etiology. This option is inappropriate in this case.
  • • Option C. Oral Antibiotics x 7 days:
  • • Option D. Needle biopsy: A needle biopsy is contraindicated in cases of suspected vascular lesions due to the risk of hemorrhage. The mass must first be evaluated with imaging to exclude vascular etiology.
  • • Option D. Needle biopsy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A pulsatile mass requires initial assessment with Doppler ultrasound to rule out vascular causes such as aneurysms or arteriovenous malformations. Advanced imaging like CT angiography is reserved for further evaluation after confirmation of vascular involvement. Invasive procedures like needle biopsy are contraindicated until a vascular lesion is ruled out.
  • ➤ A pulsatile mass requires initial assessment with Doppler ultrasound to rule out vascular causes such as aneurysms or arteriovenous malformations.
  • ➤ pulsatile mass
  • ➤ Doppler ultrasound
  • ➤ Advanced imaging like CT angiography is reserved for further evaluation after confirmation of vascular involvement.
  • ➤ Invasive procedures like needle biopsy are contraindicated until a vascular lesion is ruled out.
